user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_connection_values_n:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN int
MHD_get_connection_values_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                             MHD_KeyValueIteratorN iterator,
                             void *iterator_cls)
{
  int ret;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == connection)
    return -1;
  ret = 0;

  if (NULL == iterator)
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    {
      if (0 != (kind & pos->kind))
        ret++;
    }
  else
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
      if (0 != (kind & pos->kind))
      {
        ret++;
        if (MHD_NO == iterator (iterator_cls,
                                pos->kind,
                                pos->header,
                                pos->header_size,
                                pos->value,
                                pos->value_size))
          return ret;
      }
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (MHD_NO == iterator (iterator_cls,
                                pos->kind,
                                pos->header,
                                pos->header_size,
                                pos->value,
                                pos->value_size))
          return ret;
explanation: The remaining code constructs do not indicate statically unreachable code and therefore do not require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1: - The loops (for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)) are standard traversal constructs whose bodies execute only when the list is non-null; they are reachable when the list contains elements. - The conditional checks (if (NULL == iterator) and if (0 != (kind & pos->kind))) merely select execution paths and do not themselves create unreachable code. - The initialization of local variables (int ret; struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos; ret = 0;) and the bitmask test are ordinary, reachable statements. The three fragments listed above are flagged because they are the function's explicit return points (including the early exit when connection is NULL and the conditional early return inside the iterator-callback path) and the final return; these are the locations that could render subsequent code unreachable and therefore warrant inspection for compliance with Rule 2.1.
